journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: A study of the effects of diesel–biodiesel–bioethanol fuels on emission reduction in a compression ignition engine

article-meta.aff: 1Graduate School of Hanyang University, Sungdong-gu, Seoul, Republic of Korea
2Departments of Mechanical and Automotive Engineering, Induk University, Nowon-gu, Seoul, Republic of Korea
3Department of Mechanical Engineering, Hanyang University, Sungdong-gu, Seoul, Republic of Korea

author-notes.corresp: *Department of Mechanical Engineering, Hanyang University, 17 Haengdang-dong, Sungdong-gu, Seoul 133-791, Republic of Korea. email: cslee@hanyang.ac.kr

abstract.p: This study describes the effects of diesel–biodiesel–bioethanol blending fuels on the combustion and emission characteristics of a compression ignition engine. The experiments were investigated for various blending ratios and various fuel injection parameters. In this study, biodiesel fuel was blended not only to prevent phase separation between bioethanol and diesel but also to compensate for the low viscosity of bioethanol. The bioethanol blending ratio is restricted up to 30 vol. % to maintain the ignition characteristics. The results showed that the ignition delay was extended and that the fuel consumption and the maximum rate of pressure rise deteriorated with increasing bioethanol blending ratio. In addition, the diesel–biodiesel–bioethanol fuel reduced the indicated specific soot emissions. As the bioethanol blending ratio is increased, the indicated specific carbon monoxide (CO), the indicated specific unburned hydrocarbon, and the indicated specific nitrogen oxide emissions increased slightly.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Facing the depletion of fossil fuels and the need to reduce greenhouse gases, various technologies are being developed in many countries. An improvement in the thermal efficiency of the power system in the power plant and automotive vehicles is the most important factor in solving these problems. In this situation, the compression ignition (CI) engine is part of the solution to the energy crisis because of its excellent high thermal efficiency and low carbon monoxide (CO) and unburned hydrocarbon (HC) emissions compared with the spark ignition engine. On the other hand, the CI engine is known to generate excessive amounts of nitrogen oxides (NOx) and particulate matter (PM). Several studies have indicated that exposure to high concentrations of NOx and PM emissions is associated with an increase in the morbidity and sometimes even an increase in the mortality of the human body [1, 2]. However, it is difficult to reduce NOx and PM emissions simultaneously owing to their trade-off relationship. To reduce noxious exhaust emissions, many researchers have tried to reduce NOx and PM emissions simultaneously [3, 4]. There are three main methods utilized to achieve this: developing advanced combustion technologies, applying after-treatment technologies, and using alternative fuels. In particular, the use of alternative fuels in existing engines has the advantage of minimal modification to engine systems. Oxygenated fuels such as biodiesel, dimethyl ether (DME), and diesel–ethanol blends have been studied to improve the reduction in the exhaust emissions of the CI engine [5–11].

Regarding bioethanol fuel as a kind of renewable fuel, there have been many studies that applied diesel–ethanol blends to the CI engine [12–14]. Although bioethanol has a weak soot tendency which can be an advantage, the use of bioethanol blended diesel fuel also has limitations, such as a lower lubricity, a lower viscosity, a reduced cetane number, and a lower miscibility [14, 15]. Despite these difficulties, there has been much interest in investigating the influence of bioethanol blends containing up to 15 vol. % bioethanol.

This work was conducted with the aim of contributing to the utilization of partly renewable bioethanol–biodiesel fuel in diesel blends in an unmodified diesel engine. Thus, this study was performed to analyse the effect of the diesel–biodiesel–bioethanol blending ratios on the fuel injection parameters, such as the injection methods (single injection and pilot injection) and the injection timings on the combustion and emission characteristics in a four-cylinder direct-injection diesel engine at a constant engine speed and constant load.

sec.title: 2.1 Test fuels
sec.p: The physical properties of ultra-low-sulphur diesel (ULSD), biodiesel, and bioethanol are listed in Table 1. The cetane number is an important factor because a high cetane number influences the cold-start ability and prevents engine knocking. Although bioethanol has a low cetane number, good volatility can assist the mixing of air and fuel during ignition delay. Its high latent heat of vaporization compared with that of ULSD can also reduce the combustion chamber temperature.

caption.p: Detailed specifications of the ULSD, biodiesel, and bioethanol fuels

sec.p: Unlike gasoline, diesel fuel does not blend easily with bioethanol under all conditions. Therefore, pure diesel–bioethanol blends can result in fuel instability owing to phase separation. To overcome this problem, Park et al. [16] showed that a 5 vol. % blend of biodiesel and a closed condition can prevent phase separation of diesel–bioethanol–biodiesel blends. Thus, at least 5 vol. % biodiesel is added to diesel–bioethanol blends. In particular, bioethanol has a lower viscosity than ULSD does, which means that the injection systems may be easily damaged during the repeated fuel supply–return process in the engine. Thus, the blending ratio of biodiesel should be changed from 5 vol. % to 15 vol. % according to the bioethanol blending ratio. In this experiment, blended fuels are investigated for four kinds of fuel: ULSD, DB5E10 (ULSD, 85 vol. %; biodiesel, 5 vol. %; bioethanol, 10 vol. %), DB10E20 (ULSD, 70 vol. %; biodiesel, 10 vol. %; bioethanol, 20 vol. %), and DB15E30 (ULSD, 55 vol. %; biodiesel, 15 vol. %; bioethanol, 30 vol. %). Figure 1 shows the experimental properties of the test fuels to confirm the effect of the biodiesel blending ratio. The surface tensions and viscosities of test fuels are decreased in accordance with the increase in the bioethanol fraction as illustrated in Figs 1(b) and (c), but the specific gravities of the blended fuels showed similar values to that of ULSD. In this experiment, the blending ratio of bioethanol is restricted to 30 vol. %.

caption.p: Physical properties of the test fuels: (a) specific gravity; (b) surface tension; (c) viscosity

sec.title: 2.2 Apparatus and procedures
sec.p: The experimental apparatus is composed of four parts: a diesel engine; a fuel supply system and high-pressure injection system; the engine control system; the devices to analyse the combustion and emission characteristics. Figure 2 shows the schematic diagram of the experimental apparatus of the test engine.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the experimental apparatus (ECU, electronic comtrol unit)

sec.p: In this study, the experiment was performed using a four-cylinder common-rail direct-injection diesel engine with a displacement of 1.582 l and a maximum fuel injection pressure of 160 MPa. Table 2 summarizes the specifications of the experimental apparatus in this work.

caption.p: Detailed specifications of the test engine (BTDC, before top dead centre; ABDC, after bottom dead centre; BBDC, before bottom dead centre; ATDC, after top dead centre)

tr.td: Four-stroke variable-geometry turbocharger direct-injection diesel engine
Intake valve open; intake valve closed
Exhaust valve open; exhaust valve closed

sec.p: The engine control system consists of an eddy current dynamometer (Froude AG150) and control unit. In order to control the engine, a control program (ETAS INCA V5.4) and an electronic control unit (Bosch EDC16 ETK) are installed. A pressure sensor (Kistler 6057ASP) is used to detect the combustion pressure in the combustion chamber, and a crank angle (CA) sensor is used. Data (7200 samples per cycle) are obtained in real time using a data acquisition board (NI PCI 6251 and SC2345) and software (NI LabVIEW 8.2) to analyse the combustion characteristics. The noxious exhaust gases from the engine were measured with an emission analyser (Horiba MEXA-554JKNOx) and a smoke meter (AVL 415S).
For the calculation of emission data to convert to the indicated specific units, the equations are

In these equations, IS-X (g/kW h) is the indicated specific concentration of the component gas X, A is the constant of unit conversion, Mmeas is the measured concentration of the component X, mX is the molar mass of the component gas X, mexh is the molar mass of the exhaust gas,
m
·
is the exhaust flowrate, Ni is the indicated output, and ρexh is the density of the exhaust gas. The CO, HC, NOx, and soot emissions were converted to the indicated specific units using equations (1) and (2).

An experiment was performed to investigate the effect of the diesel–biodiesel–bioethanol blending ratio on the combustion and emission characteristics. In this work, conventional diesel fuel is compared with DB5E10, DB10E20, and DB15E30. The experiments were conducted with various blending ratios and various injection timings at an engine speed of 1500 r/min and an engine load of 90 N m. The influence of diesel–biodiesel–bioethanol blending on the combustion and emissions reduction characteristics are investigated for the two injection strategies such as a single injection with 0–12° CA BTDC and a pilot injection with 18–33° CA BTDC. Also, the single-injection timing is fixed at 3° CA BTDC, and the injection quantity of the pilot injection is 1.2 mg. For each test, the fuel injection quantities are controlled by the injection control system to fit the engine load.

sec.title: 3.1 Effects of the diesel–biodiesel–bioethanol blending on the combustion and heat release
sec.p: Figures 3(a) and (b) show the cylinder pressures, the rate of heat release (ROHR), and the accumulated heat release for various bioethanol blending ratios when the injection timing is 3° CA BTDC for a single injection and a pilot injection. In this work, the ignition delay means the time interval from the start of fuel injection to the release of 5 per cent of the total heat energy of combustion, and a definition of the combustion duration is from the release of 5–95 per cent of the total heat energy of combustion in the engine.

caption.p: Combustion characteristics for various blending ratios of fuels for a single injection at 3° CA BTDC: (a) effect of the blending ratio of fuels on the combustion pressure and the ROHR at 3° CA BTDC; (b) effect of the blending ratio of fuels on the accumulated heat release at 3° CA BTDC

sec.p: As shown in Fig. 3(a), the diesel–biodiesel–bioethanol blends retarded the ignition delay owing to the low cetane number of bioethanol. In the case of DB15E30 fuel, the combustion starts about 2.5° CA later than that of ULSD. This promotes the premixed combustion phase depending on the bioethanol blending with the ULSD. Although similar combustion pressures are indicated for DB5E10 and ULSD, the peak combustion pressure is increased as the blending ratio of bioethanol is increased in the cases of DB10E20 and DB15E30. This is attributed to the low cetane number and good volatility of bioethanol. Figure 3(b) shows the accumulated heat releases of DB5E10, DB10E20, and DB15E30. An increase in the bioethanol blending ratio shows that the combustion duration for DB15E30 is shorter than for DB5E10 (15.3° CA at DB15E30 and 19.9° CA at DB5E10), because bioethanol is an oxygenated fuel and is easy to burn owing to rapid premixed combustion. A longer ignition delay also affects the combustion duration. The results presented here indicate that diesel–biodiesel–bioethanol blends have a greater heat release of premixed combustion than conventional diesel fuel does.

Figure 4(a) shows the effect of the pilot-injection timing on the combustion characteristics using DB5E10. The ignition delay is shorter with a pilot injection than without it; however, the effects of the pilot injection on the ignition delay are decreased when the pilot-injection timing is advanced. This is because the pilot injection can create an environment in which burning is easy and can reduce the rate of pressure rise. To investigate the effect of the bioethanol blending ratio, Fig. 4(b) demonstrates the combustion pressure and the ROHR for various blending ratios when the pilot-injection timing is 23° CA BTDC and the main-injection timing is fixed at 3° CA BTDC. As shown in the combustion pressure and ROHR diagram, the ignition delay increases with increase in the bioethanol blending ratio compared with the case of single injection. Also, under the same conditions, the effect of the pilot injection on the ROHR is clearly higher for higher ethanol blending ratios than for lower blending ratios and ULSD.

caption.p: Effect of the pilot injection on the combustion pressure and the ROHR: (a) effect of the advanced pilot injection timing; (b) effect of the blending ratio of fuels

sec.p: Figure 5 illustrates the influence of the bioethanol blending ratio on the maximum rate of pressure rise, (dP/dθ)max, for the single injection and the pilot injection. The value of (dP/dθ)max is an indicator of the combustion noise and the combustion pressure rise. As shown in both Fig. 5(a) and Fig. 5(b), (dP/dθ)max (i.e. the noise) is increased when the blending ratio of bioethanol is increased. The maximum values of (dP/dθ)max for the pilot-injection cases decrease for all test fuels when the pilot-injection timing is close to the main injection. In the case of the pilot injection, in particular, the maximum value of (dP/dθ)max is lower than that of a single injection regardless of the fuel. Thus, it can be seen that the pilot injection can decrease the noise.

caption.p: Effect of the blending ratio of fuels on (dP/dθ)max: (a) single injection; (b) pilot injection

: (a) single injection; (b) pilot injection

sec.p: Figure 7 shows the effect of the blending ratio of fuels on the indicated specific fuel consumption (ISFC). The lower heating value decreases as the blending ratio of bioethanol increases. Thus, in order to generate the same power output, diesel–biodiesel–bioethanol blends need larger fuel injection quantities. For this reason, the ISFC is increased as the bioethanol blending ratio increases. In the case of DB15E30, the ISFC increased especially from 7 per cent to 14 per cent in every condition compared with that for ULSD. Figure 7(b) shows the effect of the blending ratio on the ISFC with a pilot injection. The ISFC decreases as the pilot-injection timing is advanced. Comparing the injection strategies, the ISFCs at 33° CA BTDC and 28° CA BTDC are decreased compared with a single injection, while they are decreased at 23° CA BTDC and 18° CA BTDC for pilot-injection timings compared with a single injection.

caption.p: Effect of the blending ratio of fuels on the ISFC: (a) single injection; (b) pilot injection

sec.title: 3.2 Effects of the diesel–biodiesel–bioethanol blending on the emissions reduction characteristics
sec.p: The emission characteristics of indicated specific carbon monoxide (IS-CO) for a single injection are shown in Fig. 8(a). The IS-CO emissions of diesel–biodiesel–bioethanol blends are increased for higher bioethanol blending ratios. Figure 8(b) shows the IS-CO emissions for various blending ratios for a pilot injection. In the case of the pilot injection, the IS-CO emissions are formed similarly, regardless of the pilot-injection timing.

caption.p: Emission characteristics of the IS-CO for various blending ratios of fuels: (a) single injection; (b) pilot injection

sec.p: Figure 9 showed the indicated specific unburned hydrocarbon (IS-HC) emissions of the single injection and pilot injection. As illustrated in these figures, the IS-HC emission indicated similar trends for all kinds of fuel. Comparing the two figures, the HC emission of higher ethanol blended fuel is higher than that of lower ethanol blended fuel. This can be explained by the fact that the cetane number becomes lower with increasing bioethanol blending ratio and it brings about unstable combustion in the cylinders. In the case of a pilot injection, the concentration of the IS-HC emission is decreased in comparison with the single injection.

caption.p: Emission characteristics of the IS-HC for various blending ratios of fuels: (a) single injection; (b) pilot injection

sec.p: Figure 10 shows the emission characteristics of indicated specific nitrogen oxides (IS-NOx) for a single injection and a pilot injection. In Fig. 10(a), the IS-NOx emissions increase when the injection timing advances owing to the higher combustion temperature. As the blending ratio of bioethanol increases, the IS-NOx emissions increase because the bioethanol fuel has an oxygenated content. Figure 10(b) shows the emission characteristics of IS-NOx for various blending ratios with a pilot injection. Although the IS-NOx emissions are slightly higher than those in the cases of DB5E10 and ULSD with a single injection, the other cases reduce the IS-NOx emissions.

caption.p: Emission characteristics of the IS-NOx for various blending ratios of fuels: (a) single injection; (b) pilot injection

sec.p: Figure 11 shows the emissions characteristics of indicated specific soot (IS-Soot) for various blending ratios of bioethanol fuel. In general, soot formation in the engine system depends strongly on the gas temperature and the equivalence ratio. The soot concentration increases for air-to-fuel equivalence ratios richer than 2.0 [17]. In the cases of a single injection and a pilot injection, the increasing bioethanol blending ratio leads to a decrease in the amount of IS-Soot emissions; it seems that the high oxygen content (34.7 vol. %) and good volatility of bioethanol can promote the mixing of air and fuel and its combustion. The IS-Soot emissions for the pilot injection are generated similarly to that with a single injection, which means that the pilot injection does not result in a reduction in the IS-Soot emissions in all the tested conditions.

caption.p: Emission characteristics of the IS-Soot for various blending ratios of fuels: (a) single injection; (b) pilot injection

sec.title: 4 Conclusions
sec.p: In this study, diesel–biodiesel–bioethanol blends such as DB5E10, DB10E20, DB15E30, and ULSD are used to investigate the effect of the bioethanol blending ratio on the combustion and emission characteristics using a four-cylinder common-rail direct-injection diesel engine with a displacement of 1.582 l. Biodiesel was blended not only to prevent phase separation between ULSD and bioethanol in the blended fuel but also to compensate for the low viscosity of bioethanol. The effects of diesel–biodiesel–bioethanol blends on the combustion and emission characteristics are investigated under the same engine speeds, the same loads, and the same fuel injection pressures for both injection strategies (a single injection and a pilot injection) and the injection timings are changed. The following conclusions are derived from the results of this study.

list-item.p: In the single injection, the ignition delay is increased as the blending ratio of bioethanol is increased. The combustion duration is shorter because bioethanol is an oxygenated fuel and it promotes rapid premixed combustion. In the case of the pilot injection, the ignition delay is shorter than without it. In particular, the effects of the pilot injection on the ignition delay are decreased with increasing blending ratio because of its low cetane number.

The maximum rate of the pressure rise and the rate of combustion are increased when the bioethanol blending ratio is higher in the case of a single injection. In order to generate the same power, diesel–biodiesel–bioethanol blends need larger fuel injection quantities because of its lower heating value. This causes the ISFC to increase with increasing bioethanol blending ratio. The maximum rate of the pressure rise is decreased and the rate of combustion is better than with a single injection regardless of the fuel in the pilot injection. Although the ISFCs are decreased at 33° CA BTDC and 28° CA BTDC, they are increased in the cases of 23° CA BTDC and 18° CA BTDC compared with a single injection.

In the case of a single injection, the IS-CO and IS-HC emissions of diesel–biodiesel–bioethanol blends showed similar trends to those of ULSD. The IS-NOx emissions are increased when the bioethanol blending ratio is increased, and IS-Soot emissions are decreased because bioethanol is an oxygenated fuel and has a good volatility. In the case of a pilot injection, the IS-NOx emissions are reduced for DB10E20 and DB15E30 because of the high latent heat of vaporization of bioethanol and the decrease in the maximum rate of the pressure rise. Regardless of the injection strategies, the IS-Soot emissions generated are similar to those of a single injection.
